messages.author: arv
messages.text: stopPropagation needs a comment

messages.author: arv
messages.text: preventDefault needs a comment

messages.author: SeRya
messages.text:
On 2012/06/13 19:33:52, arv wrote:

Done.

messages.author: SeRya
messages.text:
On 2012/06/13 19:33:52, arv wrote:

Done.

messages.author: arv
messages.text: Why? It is better to use bubbling when possible.

messages.author: arv
messages.text: strange indentation

messages.author: arv
messages.text: The reason this and endDrag were public and took an event was that it allows someone to initiate the drag. I guess we do not use this so it is fine to make this changes. We should probably make startDrag private too then?

messages.author: arv
messages.text: can you rename to isTouch or isTouchEvent?

messages.author: arv
messages.text: Why? Can' we allow the user to resize two splitters at the same time :-)

messages.author: arv
messages.text: This comment is not correct any more. Please update.

messages.author: arv
messages.text: @private

messages.author: SeRya
messages.text:
On 2012/06/13 19:33:52, arv wrote:
> Why? It is better to use bubbling when possible.

Reverted.

messages.author: SeRya
messages.text:
On 2012/06/13 19:33:52, arv wrote:
> strange indentation

Fixed.

messages.author: SeRya
messages.text:
On 2012/06/13 19:33:52, arv wrote:
> The reason this and endDrag were public and took an event was that it allows
> someone to initiate the drag. I guess we do not use this so it is fine to make
> this changes. We should probably make startDrag private too then?

It still is true. I initiate drag from TableHeader. It is because I want to have touch sensitive area much larger than mouse sensitive one.

messages.author: SeRya
messages.text:
On 2012/06/13 19:33:52, arv wrote:
> can you rename to isTouch or isTouchEvent?

Done.

messages.author: SeRya
messages.text:
On 2012/06/13 19:33:52, arv wrote:
> Why? Can' we allow the user to resize two splitters at the same time :-)

It's for start. Lets' file an issue to support reasonable amount of simultaneous drags. I guess 20 will be enough :-)

messages.author: SeRya
messages.text:

Commented.

messages.author: SeRya
messages.text:
On 2012/06/13 19:33:52, arv wrote:

Done.

messages.author: arv
messages.text:
On 2012/06/15 13:44:36, SeRya wrote:
> On 2012/06/13 19:33:52, arv wrote:
> > The reason this and endDrag were public and took an event was that it allows
> > someone to initiate the drag. I guess we do not use this so it is fine to make
> > this changes. We should probably make startDrag private too then?
> 
> It still is true. I initiate drag from TableHeader. It is because I want to have
> touch sensitive area much larger than mouse sensitive one.

This could have been achieved with checking the type of the event. Now every caller has to do this.

I'm fine with this even though I slightly would have preferred passing in (MouseEvent|TouchEvent)

messages.author: SeRya
messages.text:
It could indeed. However I feed that code gets more clear if receives parameters that it going to use directly rather than receiving a generic parameter and extracting that values in different ways depending on actual type.

On 2012/06/15 16:21:07, arv wrote:
> On 2012/06/15 13:44:36, SeRya wrote:
> > On 2012/06/13 19:33:52, arv wrote:
> > > The reason this and endDrag were public and took an event was that it allows
> > > someone to initiate the drag. I guess we do not use this so it is fine to
> make
> > > this changes. We should probably make startDrag private too then?
> > 
> > It still is true. I initiate drag from TableHeader. It is because I want to
> have
> > touch sensitive area much larger than mouse sensitive one.
> 
> This could have been achieved with checking the type of the event. Now every
> caller has to do this.
> 
> I'm fine with this even though I slightly would have preferred passing in
> (MouseEvent|TouchEvent)

messages.author: arv
messages.text:
On 2012/06/16 14:13:08, SeRya wrote:
> It could indeed. However I feed that code gets more clear if receives parameters
> that it going to use directly rather than receiving a generic parameter and
> extracting that values in different ways depending on actual type.

Fair enough. My concern was that the caller needs to know a lot more than desired and it might lead to duplicate code.
